description: From Latin circumstantia + English -al, equivalent to circumstance +‎ -ial.

adjectives.description: circumstantial (comparative more circumstantial, superlative most circumstantial)

entries.meaning: Pertaining to or dependent on circumstances, especially as opposed to essentials; incidental, not essential.
Abounding with minor circumstances; in great detail; particular.
examples: My Unkle's account is more circumstantial I must confess—but I believe mine is the true one for all that.

entries.meaning: Full of circumstance or pomp; ceremonial.
(law) Suggesting guilt, but not proving it conclusively.
examples: It is unlikely he will be convicted; the evidence against him is circumstantial at best.

entries.meaning: (chiefly in the plural) Something incidental to the main subject, but of less importance.
